channel.title: Getting my java files to run on cmd prompt

item.title: Getting my java files to run on cmd prompt
item.dc:creator: @Palmiz Palmiz
item.description:
@Palmiz wrote:

I don’t know the habits of this forum. But you really shouldn’t remove your question after you fixed it. No matter how stupid it was, someone else will be searching for the same thing. Post how you fixed it for future reference.

And I’ve never liked NetBeans (It’s a matter of taste of course) so I would say: Use Eclipse or IntelliJ Community Edition.

Read full topic

item.title: Getting my java files to run on cmd prompt
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I would actually recommend you consider using an Integrated Development Environment such as Eclipse or NetBeans, both of which are superb. They automatically link to whatever Java environment you have setup, so long as you have one setup, so for a beginner, nothing’s easier.

Read full topic
item.source: Getting my java files to run on cmd prompt

item.title: Getting my java files to run on cmd prompt
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

The compiler doesn’t actually run the files, it just compiles them so they can be ran.

en.wikipedia.org

Java compiler

A Java compiler is a compiler for the programming language Java. The most common form of output from a Java compiler is Java class files containing platform-neutral Java bytecode, but there are also compilers that gives optimized native machine code for a particular hardware/operating system combination. Most Java-to-bytecode compilers, Jikes being a well known exception, do virtually no optimization, leaving this until run time to be done by the JRE.[citation needed] The Java virtual machine (JV...

You must run the code, e.g. instead of javac file you would do java file. So if you wanted to run it you could open CMD, and do:

cd /directory your files are in/
java mainfile

Or use an IDE and just hit run

Read full topic
